item.question: Which of the following is true for Open Source?
item.choice: The source code is freely available
You can do whatever you want with the source code and executables
item.correct_answer: The source code is freely available
item.hint: The term Open Source is a source of continuous debate. Fortunately, there is an Open Source Initiative that maintains the Open Source definition. You can find it at http://www.opensource.org/. One item of the definition is Free distribution, which means the source code must be freely available to anyone without requiring a fee. However, the distributor may ask for a fee to cover additional costs like bandwidth, storage media, etc. etc.

item.question: Which tool allows you to create a new public/private keypair for <font face="monospace">ssh</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show the contents of all files side-by-side?
item.hint: The question asks for all files. This means you can discard two choices immediately. As you want the contents of all files side-by-side <font face="monospace">paste</font> will need to know about the different files. Passing text through standard input will discard this information.

item.question: Which command will delete the environment variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: Redefining a variable with empty input will not remove the variable. Although most of the time the difference is not noticeable when the option <font face="monospace">-u</font> is set for Bash unset variables will invoke an error when they are expanded. Expansion is requested when you precede the variable name with a <font face="monospace">$</font>. Whenever you want to manipulate the actual variable you should use the variable name without preceding it with a <font face="monospace">$</font>.

item.question:
Consider the following command:
What will be the result?
item.choice: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The primary bash prompt includes the current working directory and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and full hostname
item.correct_answer: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
item.hint: The macro's used by the shell usually use the first letter of the spelled out name.

item.question: You are asked to analyze the permissions for the files <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> and <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> on a RedHat system. Which of the following options would you use to keep the passwords secure and the system usable.
item.hint: Debian and RedHat both use different default permissions on the file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font>. However, the purpose is the same: <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> should be readable by everyone, <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> should only be readable by specific users.

item.question: You are migrating the home directories to a new server. Which of the following commands allows you to create users and create the home directories only if they do not already exist?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What file contains kernel level logging information such as output from a kernel module when it is loaded?
item.hint: The question does not state what flavour and in that case you should assume a default Debian or RedHat setup. Answers that apply to either one will be considered correct.

item.question: A new department's local area network has to be connected to an existing LAN using a router. This new department's LAN uses IP addresses from 10.10.1.64/27 and the first two IP addresses there are reserved for the router and a nameserver. How many IP adresses are left for other hosts?
item.hint: Within any network range the address with the host part all zero's or one's cannot be assigned to a network interface in the network. This means that two addresses in the range can not be used. The question states that two valid ip addresses are assigned to the router and a nameserver. Therefore, you will need to subtract 4 from the total amount of addresses in the range.

item.question: Which command can you use to set limits on resources available to the processes you start from a shell?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The ________ file is the configuration file for <font face="monospace">ntpd</font>.
item.hint: The question does not state explicitly if you should include the path as well. Therefore, you may assume it does not matter and both are considered correct.

item.question: You need to print 10 copies of the document <font face="monospace">atcomputing.txt</font>. Which of the following commands would you use?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">lpr</font> accepts a document to print through standard input or can read a document itself. Remember that <font face="monospace">></font> will write the standard output to a file. Also note that often a <font face="monospace">#</font> is interpreted as amount.

item.question: Your company policy requires employees to change their password once every 6 months and demands that a user-account will be disabled if the user fails to change her password within a grace period of 30 days. How would you accomplish this?
item.hint: To manipulate password ageing information the file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> must be edited. Although you can do this using a normal text-editor it is wise to use a dedicated command for this.

item.question: Which of the following lines do you usually find at the beginning of a shell script?
item.hint: When you execute a shell script as a normal command the first line is used by the kernel to determine which interpreter must be started to actually read and execute the script. Therefore, the first line should point to the shell command. Now you only need to know if the magic key is just a hash or a hash bang...

item.question: During your monthly security audit on a RedHat system you want to check if any files from the package <font face="monospace">cups</font> have changed since installation. Which command with all needed options provides you with this information?
item.hint: What you are looking for is package verification, also known as verify...

item.question: Your company policy requires temporary user's accounts to expire in 3 months. Which of the following commands would allow you to do this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You need to add user guru0 to the group students. Which of the following commands will be BEST to perform this task?
item.hint: These kind of questions are great for answering other questions, as it clearly tells you which command you can use to modify a user account. To answer this question correctly you must know which option will add the group to the user's additional groups. Although you can make the user a member of the group by changing its primary group. The question mentions adding the user to the group and not replacing acurrent group membership. So your safest bet would be to add the group to the user's additional groups.

item.question: To print a list of mails currently in the queue, which command would you use?
item.hint: We are talking about mail, not print jobs

item.question: What can you do to recover a lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA authentication key?
item.choice: Decrypt the authentication key with gpg.
A lost passphrase cannot be recovered.
Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.correct_answer: Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.hint: A lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA key cannot be retrieved using somekind of decryption technique. You can however use a cryptanalysis method to try to guess the lost passphrase. If this will be succesful during your lifetime depends on the chosen passphrase and its complexity.

item.question: Which section in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> allows you to specify the video resolutions for specific colour depths?
item.hint: A single Xorg server can manage multiple screens on multiple monitors. For each screen you can specify the video resolution and colour depth.

item.question: You want the script <font face="monospace">cleanup</font> to be executed each thursday at 04:00. Which of the following crontab entries would you use?
item.hint: The format for a user crontab entry is: minutes, hours, day of month, month, day of week, command. A <font face="monospace">*</font> means every minute, hour, day of month, etc. etc.

item.question: Considering below choices. What key combination can be used to force restarting the X server?
item.hint: Most Linux distributions running HAL have not enabled a key combination to restart the X server. Therefore, the correct answer may not even work on your system. However, in the past, all X servers would respond in the same manner to the key combination (<font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> option <font face="monospace">DontZap</font>). The question is about those X servers and the key combination that would make them restart.

item.question: Which of the following <font face="monospace">syslog</font> priorities should you use if you want to catch the most log messages?
item.hint: Syslog priorities go from low to high. A higher priority will also match on lower priorities.

item.question: Which of the following commands allows you to print the file <font face="monospace">linux.txt</font> and delete the file afterwards?
item.hint: Most linux commands try to make the options self explaining as much as possible. Thus, deletion is usually connected to an option <font face="monospace">-r</font> or <font face="monospace">-d</font>. Now you got a 50/50 chance of guessing the right answer. Although the <font face="monospace">--remove</font> might get you out of balance.

item.question: You have replaced <font face="monospace">inetd</font> with <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. What must be done after installation to ensure that your machine will work correctly?
item.choice: You must add a symbolic link from <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>.
You must convert the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to the configuration file format used by <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.
You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
You must convert and copy the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>
item.correct_answer: You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
item.hint: <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> is backwards compatible with <font face="monospace">inetd</font>. This does not mean that <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> will just read the same configuration files as <font face="monospace">inetd</font> does. However, if you look at the possible choices only one will match this description. Note the direction of the symbolic link that is made in one of the options...

item.question: Which of the following lines from a <font face="monospace">syslog</font> configuration file would sent all log messages to the remote log server <font face="monospace">loggy.atcomputing.nl</font>
item.hint: Syslog uses facilities and priorities to differentiate log messages. The facility and priority are separated by a dot. Although there is not a general consensus on what to use for all, the asterisk (*) is often used to specify all. In computer science the @ symbol is often used to refer to a different host on a network.

item.question: Which of the following are mail transfer agents?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the purpose of the file <font face="monospace">xdm-config</font> for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>? (Choose the best answer)
item.choice: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
It is a graphical tool to configure <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.correct_answer: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Where is the queue directory for the CUPS system usually found? (provide the full directory-path)
item.hint: The default location for queues is under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>. In computer science, spool refers to the process of placing data in a temporary working area for another program to process. Each system that requires a spool creates its own directory under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>, usually named after the system that uses it.

item.question: A user says she would like to use <font face="monospace">joe</font> as her default editor. Which of the following files would you edit to make sure the editor is always set as default when the user logs in?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: When using the command <font face="monospace">useradd</font> which option can be used to specify the user's home directory?
item.hint: The question is not about creating the user's homedirectory when adding a new user but specifying the location of the homedirectory.

item.question:
Complete the following command to make sure no one, except root, can log in.
touch /etc/
item.hint: Only provide the text that should follow the given command. Do not retype the complete command.

item.question: Which of the following would be best to use to make programs show time messages in the dutch locale?
item.hint: Although in theory multiple choices are correct the question asks about the best choice. Therefore, you should pick the one that most specifically answers the question and will always work (i.e. not dependent on a specific environment).

item.question: Which of the following configuration files is used to configure access through XDMCP for remote X11 clients?
item.hint: In this case the hint is in the question ;)............ access.\nThe file xdm.conf is the main configuration file and usually specifies other files to hold specific configuration information. The Xsession is used by the program Xsession that will run as the user's session and setup the user's X environment. The file Xresources usually contains parameters for X widgets, such as color, size, etc.

item.question: What is the output when the above shell script executes?
item.choice: The contents of the file guru.
No output but a file named guru is created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider above output from a SQL select statement. What would be the result if you execute the following SQL statement?
UPDATE users SET Rank = "Senior"
item.choice: Nothing as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
Error as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
item.correct_answer: All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
item.hint: By default SQL will affect all rows unless specified otherwise.

item.question: A possible problem with running scripts is that a mistake can lead to an explosure of new processes. This may result in the system becoming unresponsive. How can you minimize the impact of these mistakes?
item.choice: Include the line <font face="monospace">ulimit -u 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/profile</font>.
Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Include the line <font face="monospace">* soft nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Find the user who wrote the script and have a good talk about programming practices
item.correct_answer: Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
item.hint: When a process reaches its soft limit it will be denied any more of the limited resource. However, a user is allowed to increase the soft limit up to the hard limit. You can also think of it as the soft limit being a default and the hard limit being the absolute maximum.

item.question: When installing the X Window System the monitor was not correctly detected. Fortunately you found the technical specifications of the monitor. Which <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> section would you edit to specify the correct values for the monitor?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">Modeline</font> is used in <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> to provide information about a certain monitor and how to set it to a specified resolution. However it is not a section in the <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> file. The section <font face="monospace">Screen</font> specifies the default color depth and resolution you want to set the monitor too. However, it does not specify the technical aspects of the monitor like refresh rate and display size.

item.question:
Which command will tell you the geometry of a X window application?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: Sometimes the command name says it all. You require information regarding a X window...

item.question:
Consider the following commandline:
What does the above commandline do?
item.choice: Syntax error as an opening bracket must be preceeded by an <font face="monospace">if</font>-keyword.
Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
Check if <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> has execution permissions and if so will not execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
Simultaneously run two instances of <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
item.correct_answer: Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">&&</font> is a logical AND which is evaluated in a lazy manner from left to right. This means that if the left program fails the next program or programs are not executed. The <font face="monospace">[</font> is an actual program that implements a test operation. It will stop with exit code 0 if the test passes and will return an exit code other than 0 if the test fails.

item.question: Which of the following websites are good resources for known security problems, and for obtaining patches and updates for vulnerable applications?
item.hint: Sorry, no hint for this one. You either know 'em or you don't.

item.question: Which of the following options for <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> will start the X server with a black background for the root window?
item.hint: Ok, <font face="monospace">b</font> stands for black, <font face="monospace">r</font> stands for root.

item.question: The directory _______ is used to hold files and directories used as template for a new user's homedirectory. (Provide the absolute pathname)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the following partial output from a linux system configuration file.
Which of the following files includes above output?
item.hint: The file shows service names with their associated portnumbers as assigned by IANA.

item.question: Which command can be used to add a new user on the server webserver?
item.hint: This question can be tricky if you do not know the answer directly. The reason is that it asks for adding a new user on a certain server. However, the server does not matter in this case. The question could just as easily be rephrased as follows: Which command can be used to add a new user?.

item.question: Which of the following statements best describes the output in above exhibit.
item.choice: All sources will be inquired once every 64 seconds.
The system will synchronize with <font face="monospace">ams1.x31.com</font> or <font face="monospace">243-51-223.ftth</font> or <font face="monospace">ntp0.mediamatic</font>.
The system clock is running slow.
The system will synchronize with <font face="monospace">sip.dicode.nl</font> or <font face="monospace">europium.canoni</font>.
item.correct_answer: All sources will be inquired once every 64 seconds.
The system clock is running slow.
item.hint: With <font face="monospace">ntpq</font> you can see which remote timeservers are used as time synchronization sources. The character at the beginning of each line specifies the status of the candidate. A <font face="monospace">*</font> means it is used as the system peer and it is used as the time synchronization source. A <font face="monospace">+</font> means it is a possible candidate. A <font face="monospace">-</font> means it has been discarded as a possible time synchronization source. The column poll shows the interval in seconds at which the time source is polled. The offset shows the difference between the local time and the remote time. A positive offset means the local time is running behind.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user logs in and starts a login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a login shell.

item.question: What does the syslog facility <font face="monospace">uucp</font> stand for?
item.hint: Although it is hardly used on Linux you might have encountered it setting up logging services. If you did, then as a curious sysadmin you immediately looked it up on the interweb ;-). If you didn't, well it probably has to do something with Unix.....

item.question: Which of the following tools allows you to protect the system from normal users creating a denial of service using a so-called fork bomb?
item.hint: A fork bomb is a simple program that creates many processes continuously. To protect a system against a fork bomb you will need to limit the amount of processes a single user may run simultaneously.

item.question: Which of the following is the best way to list all defined shell variables?
item.hint: Variables may or may not be included in a programs environment. You use the <font face="monospace">export</font> command to add a variable to the list of variables that should automatically be included in a programs environment.

item.question: The correct command to view ALL line printer queues is?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You notice that the automatic configuration of <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> fails. You now want to generate a configuration file for <font face="monospace">Xorg</font>. Which of the following commands allows you to generate a template configuration file?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">xf86config</font> is used by the XFree86 implementation of the X Window System. The question is about the Xorg implementation.

item.question: Consider above exhibit. Which of the following statements about <font face="monospace">/var/log/rpmpkgs</font> is true?
item.choice: It is rotated once a week
If the file is missing it will be recreated
It does not exist on Linux system
item.correct_answer: It is rotated once a week
item.hint: The exhibit shows the partial contents of a configuration file for <font face="monospace">logrotate</font>. Usually there are also some global settings, however these are not shown. Therefore, you cannot know for sure that the file, if missing, will be recreated after rotation. The option <font face="monospace">notifempty</font> refers to <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> not rotating this file if it is empty.

item.question: You just started your new job as sysadmin and stumble upon a system that still uses passwords in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. Which of the following tools allows you to convert the password system to the “shadowed password file”?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following tools would you use to check if a remote system is correctly connected to a network on the network layer?
item.hint: DNS is at the application layer and not the network layer. A protocol that is at the network layer is the Internet Protocol (IP).

item.question: You use above <font face="monospace">enscript</font> command regularly to print out a nice formatted version of you scripts. How can you convert above command easily into a single word command and allow you to specify the script file as an argument for the new single word command?
item.choice: Download the source code for <font face="monospace">enscript</font>, modify it to make my options default, compile and install it.
Post a bug report asking the developers to make my options the default.
item.hint: The question is about an easy way.

item.question: Which of the following is the default <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> configuration file?
item.hint: This one is actually pretty easy if you think about it. There is only one choice that specifies the configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>. Because you know that the default location for configuration files is under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> (according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard) your best bet would be that choice.

item.question: To get a list of all active network connections you issue the command?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following lines would you expect to see in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts.allow</font>?
item.hint: The format of the <font face="monospace">hosts.allow</font> file is service name (proces name) followed by the access control rule or rules.

item.question: A user calls and complains that he/she cannot work with the text-editor that is started when he/she wants to write an email using a text-oriented mailprogram like <font face="monospace">mutt</font> or <font face="monospace">pine</font>. Which file is best to edit to define a different default text-editor?
item.hint: The skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for an existing user and only a single user. Therefore, it boils down to knowing the difference between <font face="monospace">.bashrc</font> and <font face="monospace">.bash_profile</font>.
